posts.name: Alexandru Theodor Muntenas
posts.cooked: I think it is important to know who are the expected end users that join the Signal family, before continuing the task of spreading the voice to invite more people to join the service.

posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked: Signal is designed for everyone! I use Signal every day to talk with friends and family, and have done so for over 5 years.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
If they have a smartphone and use a messaging app, they are the intended user. Signal is designed to be secure without ever having to know what an encryption key is. My 73 year-old grandmother set it up herself and we talked on it every day.

I‚Äôve used Signal since 2017, exclusively since 2023.

Signal is for everyone: privacy conscious you, your risen with TikTok and Instagram kids,who think that privacy is some outdated concept and your elderly grandma who doesn‚Äôt even know word ‚Äúcybersecurity‚Äù. The idea is that Signal should give you security and privacy somewhat by the way, when you‚Äôre using it. No matter whether you‚Äôre tech savvy or just install app and use it never looking inside settings,

Screenshot / recording detection and/or blocking

But, again, the common user that joins Signal cames from WhatsApp / Telegram.

I would say that your assumption posted in another thread is wrong.

Signal is providing a service and clients to anyone who wants to use them. It is not trying to take ‚Äúcustomers‚Äù from Whatsapp, Telegram, nor any other platform. Personally, I have never used Whatsapp, Telegram, Snapchat, Line, nor Facebook Messenger. Each of those can have its benefits for its own userbase. While Whatsapp is used all over Europe, it isn‚Äôt used at all in China, and is still very uncommon in North America.

posts.name: Alexandru Theodor Muntenas
posts.cooked:
Sorry for my lack of information. I should have informed my self better. A bunch of people here in Spain we‚Äôre trying to remove WhatsApp presence due to privacy concerns. We‚Äôre really worried about what‚Äôs happening with digital privacy. And we‚Äôre making the effort to try to protect as much people as possible.

For my part, sometimes it is difficult to break this european-centric pov. It‚Äôs kinda difficult, but thank you for pointing out

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
i‚Äôd like to expand upon what others said in this thread and specifically say that the vision of Signal is to give a strong privacy tool that would fit even people like Snowden to the everyday person. so Signal‚Äôs target user is everyone, but the first condition before that is uncompromising privacy, which is why (unlike some other ‚Äúsecure‚Äù messengers) Signal doesn‚Äôt offer unencrypted chats, nor does it offer plain-text backups, and other convenience features of that sort that will create two tiers of security.
Signal‚Äôs vision is for everyone to be using the app, and even in that world, for Signal >> Government Communication to still only have the two parameters as always: date joined, date last connected, and nothing more.

signal messenger tries to be general app for general population, which includes novice users and also pro users.

i get it easy to use and install. but i also want pro user options as well. installing without google play is not easy. signal is still too much dependent on google play store and apple app store. other options are barely supported.

DirkPitt1:

‚Ä¶ TikTok and Instagram kids,who think that privacy is some outdated concept ‚Ä¶

i classify two kinds of privacy, can friends, relatives and neighbors know my stuff, or are data stored on a worldwide faceless corporate datacenters. my friends can know my stuff to a certain degree, but my data does not belong to corporate power for monetization and using against us. i think this is a key point of privacy battle. most people think some personal issues.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
zetabeta:

installing without google play is not easy.

The APK has been available to side-load for years: Signal >> Signal Android APK

zetabeta:

i think this is a key point of privacy battle. most people think some personal issues.

Unfortunately too many people still think that ‚Äúprivacy‚Äù means ‚Äúhaving something to hide‚Äù instead of ‚Äúbeing able to decide whom you want to share something with‚Äù.

posts.name: Jj
posts.cooked:
Just like everyone agrees that Signal is for everyone there are some use cases that aren‚Äôt best supported.

I wouldn‚Äôt use Signal as the main communication channel for a medium/large company. Meta has a Whatsapp Business client that‚Äôs specifically suited to run B2C communications, and in many comparisons of WA to Signal, this may be one where Signal doesn‚Äôt compete.

Similarly, unlike Whatsapp and Telegram, Signal is not appropriate for massive broadcast groups. The group support in telegram are meant to be on the smaller size and not an evergrowing/unmanaged number of members (akin to Telegram or WA channels)

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
jjdelc:

Meta has a Whatsapp Business client that‚Äôs specifically suited to run B2C communications, and in many comparisons of WA to Signal, this may be one where Signal doesn‚Äôt compete.

Facebook and Signal have two very different goals.

Facebook‚Äôs mission is profit at any and all costs, even human suffering.

Signal‚Äôs charitable mission is to bring simple, private, encrypted messaging to as many people as possible for the purposes of maintaining personal freedom and combating authoritarian censorship. A business version of Signal is not aligned with that mission, and laws across the world would be incompatible with Signal‚Äôs policy of collecting as little data as possible.

posts.name: Anonymous Pony
posts.cooked:
Signal has become so user friendly that at some point I had my whole family on it. It really peaked during the pandemic.

Some people have left since then. Usually they disappear when they get a new phone and don‚Äôt install the app again, given everyone is also on WhatsApp.

WhatsApp still has a better user experience for normies, and they‚Äôve been pushing privacy-related features, probably because Signal adoption in 2020-21 frightened them. Seems META is back in control for now.

What pisses me off about WhatsApp are mostly the AI features, but otherwise you can‚Äôt see where it lacks in terms of privacy/security, without further technical analysis. It‚Äôs probably private/secure enough for practical (and marketing) purposes, and that‚Äôs why it‚Äôs now competing on UI/UX and network effects again.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: WhatsApp will always have an advantage because Facebook has hundreds of billions of dollars to throw at it.

Everyone, even the folks doing‚Ä¶questionable things. I actually use two Signal accounts. One on a secure phone and terminal and then this one. My work I do is quite sensitive engineering work for US Gov. On my time off, I just want friggin privacy from Verizon, At&T, Google, AWS and all the other. My provider doesn‚Äôt need to know what I‚Äôm talking about to my grandmother, strippers, or other engineers doing engineering stuff.

title: Who are the expected user target of the app?
